movies.title: Slipper Episode
movies.plot: A husband orders his wife to recover a lost slipper. The wife enlists the aid of her friend, Beatrice (Betty Stockfield) to bring the slipper to her in Switzerland, and Georges (Roger Treville) follows Betty.
movies.simplePlot: A husband orders his wife to recover a lost slipper. The wife enlists the aid of her friend, Beatrice (Betty Stockfield) to bring the slipper to her in Switzerland, and Georges (Roger Treville) follows Betty.

biography.bio: Betty Stockfeld was born on January 15, 1905 in Sydney, Australia as Elizabeth Stockfield. She was an actress, known for Slipper Episode (1935), The Beloved Vagabond (1936) and Lord of the Manor (1933). She was married to Aubrey St. John Edwards. She died on January 27, 1966 in Tadworth, Surrey, England.
biography.name: Betty Stockfeld

biography.bio: Roger Tréville was born on November 17, 1902 in Joigny, Yonne, France as Roger Troly. He was an actor, known for How to Steal a Million (1966), Slipper Episode (1935) and Durand contre Durand (1931). He died on September 27, 2005 in Beaumont-du-Périgord, Dordogne, France.
biography.name: Roger Tréville

biography.bio: Raymond Cordy was born on December 9, 1898 in Vitry-sur-Seine, Val-de-Marne, France as Victor Raymond Cordioux. He was an actor, known for À Nous la Liberté (1931), Le million (1931) and Beauty and the Devil (1950). He was married to Madeleine Fromet. He died on April 23, 1956 in Paris, France.
biography.name: Raymond Cordy

biography.bio: Jean Tissier was born on April 1, 1896 in Paris, France. He was an actor, known for ...And God Created Woman (1956), L'assassin habite... au 21 (1942) and The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1956). He was married to Georgette Tissier. He died on March 31, 1973 in Granville, Manche, France.
biography.name: Jean Tissier

biography.bio: Janine Guise is an actress, known for Nuits de Venise (1931), Slipper Episode (1935) and La mascotte (1935).
biography.name: Janine Guise

biography.bio: In 1930, Claude, who was a stage-struck set designer at the Oden Theater, a repertory house in Paris, learned an ailing actor's part in two hours and took it over without a rehearsal. Tristan Bernard, the famous French playwright and producer took notice of this feat. He engaged Dauphin for the leading role of his next play "La fortune" was was also made into a film the next year. Dauphin's next break came when Charles Boyer left for American movies. As Boyer left for America, Dauphin succeeded in the Henri Bernstein organization, outstanding stage producers of Paris. Prior to the outbreak of World War II, Dauphin starred in several plays as well as sixty five French made pictures. Dauphin received his elementary education at Ecole Fenelon and high school at Lycee Condorcet. he also graduated from Lycee Louis de Grand in literature and philosophy, all of these school located in Paris. Between 1940 and 1945, he was a solider in the French and allied armies. he was a lieutenant in the French tank service and shuttered later in life at his memories of that kind of grisly warfare. After the fall of France, he organized his own stock company and toured non-occupied cities and small towns. he was also serving in the French underground movement. Threatened with exposure, he escaped by buying a small fishing boat in the south of France and sailing to Gibraltar. After reaching London in 1942, he first served with the British Secret Service and then joined the Free French forces of DeGaulle. Claude quickly learned English, of which he was devoid of, and became a liaison officer between the French LeClerc division and the press corps of the American Army of General Patton. Because of this association, he was one of the first to enter Paris on Liberation Day. Dauphin's American film debut was in the movie "Deported" produced largely in Italy. He later appeared in many stage productions on Broadway including "No Exit" and "Happy Time". He later had a screen test with Warner Bros. and then returned to France. Having almost forgotten about the test, he was summoned to Hollywood for "April in Paris" starring Doris Day and Ray Bolger.
biography.name: Claude Dauphin

biography.bio: Jean Dax was born on September 17, 1879 in Paris, France as Gontran Théodore Louis Henri Willar. He was an actor, known for Mayerling (1936), Sacrifice fraternel (1915) and La nuit de la Saint Jean (1922). He died on June 6, 1962 in Paris.
biography.name: Jean Dax

biography.bio: Émile Genevois was born on January 1, 1918 in Barlin, Pas-de-Calais, France. He was an actor, known for Rififi (1955), Les misérables (1934) and Casque d'Or (1952). He died on September 19, 1962.
biography.name: Émile Genevois

biography.bio: Maryanne is an actress, known for La maternelle (1933), L'anglais tel qu'on le parle (1931) and Daïnah la métisse (1932).
biography.name: Maryanne

biography.bio: Georgette Tissier was born on June 26, 1910 in Boulogne-Billancourt, Hauts-de-Seine, France as Louise Georgette Lalire. She was an actress, known for L'amant de Bornéo (1942), Romance de Paris (1941) and Christine se marie (1946). She was married to Jean Tissier. She died on March 30, 1959 in Paris, France.
biography.name: Georgette Tissier
